SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The extra sheets of paper there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 7, entitled "Pioneer East: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

{ All questionnaires }
{ Pioneer health conditions }
{ Pioneer social life, sports and recreation }
{ Pioneer housing }
{ Pioneer education and churchwork }
{ Pioneer farming experience }

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

PLEASE PRINT ALL PROPER NAMES AND PLACE NAMES IN CAPITAL LETTERS. IF YOU ARE NOT SURE THE NAME IS CORRECT AS YOU HAVE WRITTEN IT, PLEASE SAY SO. IF POSSIBLE, THIS IS QUITE ACCEPTABLE.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Ellen Hubbard
2. Your address: Grenfell, Sask.
3. Date: March 4th, 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Uxbridge, Ontario
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   William Dunn, Carpenter
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   Nov. 24th, 1894
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving names and dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child.")

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My parents had a big family. 8 boys & 3 girls. The farmers opened their farms. We were working on the school farm and the young men were going to town to work and get to homesteads.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

Through some of town people that came there, also my father came to homesteading in 1877 but had to come back with poor health and all articles on west till he came again in 1894.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

A number of different families were coming to our farm. We came to Yarrow.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

In 1892, one man came and another with car of settlers.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

My father and brother came March 1894 and built a house on homestead.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

In 1893 my husband came; he was 15 years old.

With Frank Harris in an ox team effects, a horse fell down and at Gravel Pit yard boats said to take out a small plow & water barrel and get barrel up but have went on to John Mulford until place so I yard does telegraphed North Bay to field train for toy & plow.

Coming together.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

On Gravel Pit Mr. & Mrs. Harris, for a few days till word was got to farm.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Section 11, W. 4th, 24, 18, 8, 10 miles north east.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My father was a carpenter but died 1897 & we had to depend on farm him.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

A number of different families were coming from different parts of Western Canada. I came from our own family.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)?

In 1892, one man came in an ox team and another unit car. But in 1893 another car of settlers effects also came in March 1894 and built a house on homestead.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

My father and brother came March 1894 and built a house on homestead.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

In 1893 my husband came he was 15 years old. With Frank having in can supplies effects, a horse pack down and at Carilla the yard boys said to take out a small plow & water barrel and get railroad up but haven't went on it yet. John Hubbard went plow so I paid for telegraphed North Bay to Field train for toy express.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I'm Grumfield with Mr. & Mrs. Lawrence, for a few days till wood was got to farm.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Section N.W. 1/4, 24, 18, 8, 16 miles north.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My brother was a carpenter but died 1897 & we had to depend on farm him.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?  
   A monthly letter to relatives in Scotland and other relatives in Nebraska, but could not afford to write often to friends.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.  
   I married John Hubbard April 1st, 1907, Sunnyside, Sask.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.  
   My brother Tom came to Sunnyside in 1897 and married there for 10 years + went to Windthorst, Texas. I had a hard time there.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?  
   Previous fires, 1896 burned from 20 miles south Sunnyside to 15 miles north.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?  
   We often walked 6 or 7 miles to church as there were no cars & worked hard but often we went in wagon, or walked 5 miles to neighbor's went in wagon with them to special service at Easter or Harvest, Thanksgiving.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Previous Affairs. 1896 burned from 20 miles south.

Trunfell to 15 miles north.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

We often walked (or) miles to church as forew

We never worked hard but often we went in wagon, or walked 5 miles to neighbor's went in wagon until them to special service at Easter or Hanvad, Thanksgiving.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   /1918

26. If you owned a car before 1918, when did you buy it? What make?
   An English car until 1918, then a Ford.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your house?
   Glenwillow or Summerville, 10 or 14 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   We traded monthly at Glenwillow, but now we trade go to Millville, north.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Weekly or twice a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   We went to town to drink about 1904.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   We bought from Sears Roebuck in 1898 from an advertisement in a paper, ladies' flannel little nighties for 50 cents, very good, and 1903 ladies' cloth jackets, $3.50; my brother's flannel shirt was $1.50.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   In 1918 was our first rural telephone line built.

33. When did you come to Saskatchewan the first time? Was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   We had to stay we were to travel to move away.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   /9/08

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   An English car and it was black and hooded out.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Greenfield or Summerville, 10 or 14 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to war times appear-
   ing, better means of travel, etc.)
   We traded monthly at Greenfield, but now we trade
   go to Millville, Millville, North.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Weekly or twice a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly
   on Saturdays?
   We went to town to shop at work about 1904
   when we were open till 10 o'clock nights.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogs?
   We bought from Sears Roebuck in 1898 from
   an advertisement in a paper, ladies flannellette
   nighties, for $0.50, very good, and 1903 ladies
   cloth, for $1.00. By my brother, who lived across
   the street. But 1904 we bought 88 cottons in
   new market. But 1904 we bought 88 cottons in
   town. We also a 50 yard web at 75 cents per yard
   cotton. We today also 50 yards of blue denim, 88 orange back
   for 25 cents per yard, heavy striped flannellette 1852, we
   made sheets, etc.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   In 1912 was our first rural telephone line built.

33. When you came to Sashabawen the first time, was it with the idea of staying
   permanently? Or did you make your mind after trying it out? When did you
   make this decision?
   We had to stay we were to travel to move
   away.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Sold their farms and went into business in other towns.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

They went and came back.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

John Hubbard was Secretary of Little School district Feb. 1909 - Dec. 1944. Also President of Weldon Rural Telephone Co. Jan. 1912 - 1944 also Past President Buckeyeers Association.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention its here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, coothing, organizing the first league, etc.)

John Hubbard organized Weldon Rural Telephone Co. 1911 - April 1912. Buckeyeers, acc. about 1920

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have? (If yes, list reasons.)

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

John Hubbard was secretary to little beloved district Feb. 1909 - the 174th Sect. Trustees, Weldon Rural Telephone Co. Jan. 1912 - 1944 also sat President Buckuppers association. Dr. Marsh & honorary life member.
